WRITING.TEXT:
Tipping here is usually, but not always, done by rounding up the tab; so if the two beers were, say, 94 CZK, and you told them to keep the change, that's perfectly acceptable, especially if you're getting it at the bar. That lady at the bar jump into the sea.
As for the reservations. Your "faux-pas" wasn't only wanting to sit at a reserved table, but at *the* reserved table. At many pubs the table(s) closest to the bar is (are) reserved for the *tamgasty*, the most loyal patrons. In some places, it can take years for a regular to be accepted the tamgasty and be allowed to sit at the table, and some people tend to be VERY territorial and not particularly friendly if a stranger (and a foreigner at that) wants to sit there, especially if they have a few under their belt. Don't take the reaction of that woman personally, she would have probably reacted the same way everywhere.

En 1993 el gobierno puso en venta acciones de YPF solamente para minoristas. Yo estaba trabajando como cajero en una sucursal de Banco Ro y el banco ofreci a todos los empleados (y a los clienets VIP de las sucursales) crditos a 72 hs de 500 mangos con la condicin de que le venderamos al banco las acciones y pgabos el prstamo, si las vendamos con ganancia, la guita era para nosotros, y si no, el banco se hara cargo de cubrir la prdida. Como era de esperarse, el precio de las acciones se fue por las nubes y nos terminamos llevando un lindo premio, mientras que el banco se qued con las acciones.

No. That's not how beer is made. If you leave seeds in water just like that what nothing will ferment.
What most likely happened was that someone made a porridge or a soup with some crushed grain, cooking it enough time and at the right temperature to activate the enzymes that turn the starch in the grain into sugars, flavoured it very ripe fruit and left it unattended long enough for the concoction to cool (maybe [attract fruit flies](https://www.wired.com/2014/10/beer-yeast-attracts-fruit-flies/) and start fermenting, which can happen relatively fast.

When they are clearly out of touch with the reality of the staff.
A bunch of years ago I was working in Prague at the local branch of an international language school. We didn't have a basic salary, we got paid according to how many hours we taught each month.
When the cost of living in Prague started to go up in 2003, a few of us wrote a letter to the management politely asking for a raise and for a benefit scheme to reward the better teachers in a better way than only giving them more work.
We were told that yes, that we would soon get a raise and they would start putting together some sort of benefit scheme, but that they would need time for that.
A couple of months passed without words about the raise, or the benefits. One day, they announced with a rather big fuss that there would be a training course on communication and some other related stuff, which we were all welcome to attend. The course would be three days long, each day from 9 to 4 or 5. Oh! And we wouldn't get paid those hours. Unsurprisingly, not a single teacher signed up. For some reason, however, the management had failed to foresee that teachers may not want to loose three days of paid work for a training course nobody had bothered to ask if they wanted or needed in the fist place. Their response: to complain that, even though we had been asking for a benefit scheme, we had all refused to attend a course that was "clearly" a benefit.
Then there was that time when they refused to give me a day off because, in my supervisor's work, I was the best they had and they couldn't spare me.
By then I had already started with the paperwork to get a trade license and go free-lance, as a couple of my friends had done, and it wouldn't take me long to leave.

As for Czech, my experience in the 15 years I've been living here is that most Czechs really appreciate it when a foreigner at least tries to learn the language. When dealing with authorities, the people in the offices tend to be nicer to you if you are able to put a few words together. I remember at the ivnostensk ad -- Praha Zpad back in 2004 when I hardly spoke Czech, two ladies and one guy went as far as to use sign language to explain something I needed to do.

Cuando el servicio militar era obligatorio, el 31 de mayo de cada ao, las fuerzas armadas (o el ministerio de defensa, no s quin estaba a cargo) haca un sorteo en Lotera Nacional en donde los ltimos 3 dgitos de tu DNI era el nro. de orden al que le correspondera una bolilla con un nmero de sorteo.
De entre los mil nros. haba uno por encima del cual hacas la colimba y por debajo, te salvabas. Por lo que me acuerdo, ese nmero cambiaba todos los aos de acuerdo a varios criterios, pero en genral fue subiendo con los aos (las FF.AA. tenan menor presupuesto y no necesitaban tanta carne de can o esclavos). El nmero que saqu yo fue muy bajo y en el momento que lo dijeron saba que me haba salvado. Qu felicidad!

Las mismas pelotudeces alarmistas y vendemiedo que hoy se dicen sobre los videojuegos, se decan en su momento con la televisin (con otras palabras, quizs, pero la idea se mantiene) y sobre el rock, las historietas, y no me extraara que se hayan dicho tambin sobre la radio. Hasta sobre las novelas se decan estas forradas a fines del s. XVIII y principios del XIX. O sea, nada nuevo bajo el sol.
Soy clase 71 y uno de los das ms felices de mi vida fue el 31 de mayo de 1989, cuando, a eso de las 9 y media escucho en la radio: "orden", "6-9-9"; "sorteo", "0-8-0".

Actually, I doubt the intention of people like Chvez and Trump ever had the intention to address those social issues to begin with.

Left-wing populism (and maybe populism in general) co-opts real and serious social issues with sloganeering, promises and us vs them rhetoric. When they get to power, they start throwing money around as a short-term solution to get "the people" on their side, but never really addressing those social issues. That can last as long as there's money around.
The problems begin when money starts running out, and Venezuela is a great example of that. It didn't help either that Chvez failed to find a worthy successor and instead, and even though he knew he was dying, appointed the fuckwit of Maduro as his vice-president. But that seems to be common with populist leaders and demagogues, who rely a lot on their charisma and don't want anyone to take the spotlight from them.

Here's an [article by the American Psychological Association on hypnosis](http://www.apa.org/monitor/2011/01/hypnosis.aspx). According to it, there's been some research that has shown some positive results.
[This article](https://med.stanford.edu/news/all-news/2016/07/study-identifies-brain-areas-altered-during-hypnotic-trances.html) on how hypnosis alters brain areas among other things says that:
Only about 10 percent of the population is generally categorized as highly hypnotizable, while others are less able to enter the trancelike state of hypnosis. Spiegel and his colleagues screened 545 healthy participants and found 36 people who consistently scored high on tests of hypnotizability, as well as 21 control subjects who scored on the extreme low end of the scales.
Nothing conclusive, really

vastu shastra involves designing buildings by making the best possible use of the geography and location of the plotincluding the influence of the suns light and heat, wind directions, the moons position, and the Earths magnetic fields
The only things that could be seen as woo are the moon's position and the Earth's magnetic fields (which brings up the question, did cultures back then know about the Earth's magnetic field?). The rest seem quite sensible and, in some way or another, are applied when designing houses.
That being said, I've been to a few homes allegedly decorated according to Feng-shui and, even though I don't believe in any of that "flow of energy" nonsense, I must say they were really nice.

S, en Kilkenny en Retiro, a fines de los 90. Estaba con un amigo, nos habamos tomado 6 cervezas cada uno y ya queramos irnos. El boliche se haba llenado mucho y estuvimos sentados como mnimo media hora esperando a la piba que nos haba estado atendiendo. Haba desaparecido. Nos paramos para ver si la encontrbamos o si nos vea. Nada. De golpe nos dimos cuenta que estbamos parados al lado de la puerta y que nadie nos daba pelota, nos miramos, nos encogimos de hombros y nos fuimos. Cuando bajbamos por Marcelo T. la vimos sentada en la entrada de la coina, fumando. Ni nos registr.

Juan Jos Caram (creo que se llamaba el movilero lungo que tenan) estaba entrevistando en el hospital un chofer que haban asaltado. Al pibe lo haban disfrazado de gordo a trompadas. Caram le pregunta cmo haba ocurrido el hecho y el chofer le cuenta que los "malvivientes" se subieron al colectivo y antes de sacar boleto empezaron a amenazar a los pasajeros. Caram lo interrumpe y le pregunta, indignadsimo, "?lo asaltaron y no le pagaron el boleto?".

I've visited several Czech malthouses, including three traditional floor maltings. The practice everywhere is: they get the barley from several sources, each producing a different variety. They are stored separately and malted separately. The malt produced with them (Pilsner, mostly) will have each slightly different characteristics. Some brewers will buy a blend of different malts, others will prefer a single variety, depending on what they want for their recipes. Quite fascinating stuff, really.

I used GoEuros Beer Price Index (2015 and 2016) for beer costs around the world. This index includes both supermarket and bar costs for a 33cl beer.
Crap methodology here in Prague. The standard measure of beer is 0.5l, both bottled and draft. 0.33l bottles in supermarkets are considerably more expensive by volume than the same brand in half-litre. And only a few brands are available in that size. Regarding draft beer, the alternative size to half-litre at an overwhelming majority of places is 0.3l.

WRITING.TITLE: The Spanish Flu epidemic happens in 1916. How does that affect the course of WWI?
WRITING.TEXT: When it happened in 1918 the war was almost over. In 1916 it was still in full swing, with battles like Somme or Verdun raging and a very active Eastern front, with Russia and the AHE still fighting fiercely. The Bolshevik revolution is yet to happen. The epidemic hits specially hard in the Western Front, with the trenches providing ideal conditions for the disease to spread rapidly.

WRITING.TEXT: They would never be able to even get started. Their border regions with Bolivia, Per, Ecuador, Colombia, Venezuela, the Guyanas and Suriname are very remote and getting enough troops there would be next to impossible. There's another angle to be considered. The rise of extreme right movements (the Nazis, in Germany, and Fascism, in Italy) was to a great extent a response to the threat of Communism after WWI.
The Communists' loosing the civil war would have likely been a blow to the movement outside the Russian borders as there would have been no victorious regime producing propaganda to promote their ideology, let alone the Revolution.
It is very possible that the lack of the communist boogeyman would have affected the popularity of the far-right movements in the 1920s, giving rise, perhaps to more versions of the parties that eventually seized power in Germany and Italy.

There are officially 350 brick mortar microbreweries in the Czech Rep., plus an unknown number of letajc pivovary (flying breweries), as gypsy brewers are called here, some of which are very well regarded, and there are about 40 independent breweries. If we adhere to the commonly used definition, the number of Craft Breweries in this country would be at least 400, in a country of 10.5 million people, 38 breweries/1 mil. Quite a lot more than the UK.
